text: To be fair, they are bundling GraalVM Enterprise with Java SE now and fund the vast majority of Java new development and well as maintenance both which are not zero cost activities.

elements.text: To be fair, they are bundling GraalVM Enterprise with Java SE now and fund the vast majority of Java new development and well as maintenance both which are not zero cost activities.

text: just curious - it sounds like you know GraalVM - their getting started page doesn’t mention Julia, though it refers to LLVM a lot - any success with Julia in GraalVM?

elements.text: just curious - it sounds like you know GraalVM - their getting started page doesn’t mention Julia, though it refers to LLVM a lot - any success with Julia in GraalVM?

text: they have a JIT for LLVM bytecode, this allows them to build a partial evaluation interpreter to call anything that can be compiled to LLVM bytecode (statically) within the VM.  Ex. Java / Ruby / Javasrcipt calls some C/C++ function, but allowing for in-lining / optimization across the interface because it's all globally available within the VM.  Julia uses LLVM as a JIT so it doesn't quite work in that way as LLVM bytecode is generated and compiled at runtime on demand (if that makes sense)

text: Sounds like a transpose operation :simple_smile:  - GraalVM has JIT for LLVM, Julia has LLVM as JIT…

elements.text: - GraalVM has JIT for LLVM, Julia has LLVM as JIT…

text: or is it an adjoint operator?

elements.text: or is it an adjoint operator?
